After playing it for second time (previously on PS3 back then) the story still caught me off guard, the characters are great with me so easily being attached to both of them, the voice actors/actress are phenomenal, it's rare for me getting excited to find sound recorder collectables just to listen to the characters talking because i was so intrigued with their story telling.
Columbia city is beautiful and even after 8 years the graphic still holds up really nice and some of scenes are breathtaking and made me literally glazing upon the views/scenery for few minutes to enjoy them.

Btw this is maybe controversial for some people but i will say it:
Bioshock Infinite is my favorite between the trilogy and you can't change my mind..
It holds special place in my heart.
10/10

This game is a masterpiece and also the best of the series, but this isn't even just a game, this art and an experience.

The story felt so much better than the first 2 games, even though, those were really good as well. The twists at the and gave me goosebumps, because they're so shocking and amazingly written.

The characters are all written very well. 
Elizabeth especially, she is the real main character in the story. She really has feelings, not just in cutscenes, but trough the whole game you can see and hear her doing something. If you're out of combat she will comment on things, do thing according to the environment, etc., if you're in combat she will seek cover for herself and also get you ammo, health, and salt (basically mana). Her character is so sympathetic, kind, and good hearted, that she is easily one of the best female characters of all time.
Booker is a bit grumpy at start, but he is a very good main character, and eventually you can meet his real side and that is where will get even better.  
The Lutece twins are a very good duo, who have some time oddly hilarious moments, but they help you to get some answers along the way as well, and i really like them throug out the game.

The game also looks beautiful, I didn't even realise it was almost 9 years old.

How do you improve upon the world of Rapture with its remarkable storytelling and unforgettable characters? You create a whole new universe of infinite possibilities brought to life only by the magic of video games. Having underwent development hell before its release, BioShock Infinite ultimately succeeds in delivering what it set out to be as a fresh new installment that's enjoyable with an ambitious narrative that is contemplated upon long after its conclusion.

BioShock Infinite focuses on the relationship between the main protagonists, Jack and Elizabeth, as well as the political war between the Vox and the government. Although the story is extremely complex at times, its ethical and moral implications are rewarding if dug a little deeper. Personally, I found the opening of BioShock Infinite on par with the original BioShock. Exploring Columbia felt authentic and gave me a weird nostalgic feeling that was constantly felt throughout the whole journey. In terms of gameplay, the new Sky-Hook mechanic is awesome plus the gunplay is faster and more satisfying. Vigors were cool but didn't feel the need to use them as much as with Plasmids from BS1/BS2. Additionally, I found the AI weaker on Normal difficulty, and the Soldiers not as cool as the Splicers. However, the Handymen, Patriots, Firemen and the Boys of Silence were all quite memorable.

BioShock Infinite is more than just a game, it's a representation of what video games can accomplish in terms of storytelling. The beauty of Columbia is not only skin deep but also best described as a living breathing world filled with emotions, captivating stories, intertwined by thought provoking subplots, mixed in with philosophy and quantum physics. And just when you think it can't get any better, Burial at Sea Episode 1 & 2 elevate the experience even further. It wraps up the story perfectly and leaves me with a strong recommendation of the entire BioShock series.
it's like Bioshock but it's infinite
